main_text:
Many philosophers have maintained that altruism is a crucial component
of morality, and that people often do behave altruistically. Other
philosophers, along with many biologists and social scientists, have
claimed that facts about human psychology, or about the evolutionary
processes that have shaped human psychology, indicate that no human
behavior is genuinely altruistic. Part of this disagreement can be
traced to the fact that both philosophers and scientists use the term
“altruism” with many quite different meanings. Sections 2,
3 and 4, set out a number of widely used accounts of altruism.  One of
these, “the standard account”, has been the focus of most
of the debate in philosophy over the existence of altruism. Sections 5
and 6, review some of the most important empirical work aimed at
determining whether humans can indeed behave altruistically, on the
standard account.
